revision.text:
The '''dark triad''' in [[psychology]] refers to the personality traits of [[narcissism]], [[Machiavellianism]], and [[psychopathy]],<ref name="Paulhus & Williams 2002">{{cite journal |last1=Paulhus |first1=Delroy L |last2=Williams |first2=Kevin M |title=The Dark Triad of personality: Narcissism, Machiavellianism, and psychopathy |journal=Journal of Research in Personality |date=December 2002 |volume=36 |issue=6 |pages=556–563 |doi=10.1016/S0092-6566(02)00505-6 }}</ref><ref name="RegoliHewitt2011">{{cite book|author1=Robert M. Regoli|author2=John D. Hewitt|author3=Matt DeLisi|title=Delinquency in Society: The Essentials|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v6MTZ2WhcfIC&pg=PA99|date=20 April 2011|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Learning|isbn=978-0-7637-7790-6|page=99}}</ref><ref name="CampbellMiller2011">{{cite book|author1=W. Keith Campbell|author2=Joshua D. Miller|title=The Handbook of Narcissism and Narcissistic Personality Disorder: Theoretical Approaches, Empirical Findings, and Treatments|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gw_zHSuejdcC&pg=PA154|date=7 July 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-02924-4|page=154}}</ref><ref name="LearyHoyle2009">{{cite book|author1=Mark R. Leary|author2=Rick H. Hoyle|title=Handbook of individual differences in social behavior|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VgcGZ5sCEcIC&pg=PA100|date=5 June 2009|publisher=Guilford Press|isbn=978-1-59385-647-2|page=100}}</ref> which are called "dark" because of their malevolent qualities.<ref name="Chamorro-PremuzicStumm2011">{{cite book|author1=[[Tomas Chamorro-Premuzic]]|author2=Sophie von Stumm|author3=Adrian Furnham|title=The Wiley-Blackwell Handbook of Individual Differences|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K4yqoP4xwlEC&pg=PA527|date=23 February 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-4310-6|page=527}}</ref><ref name="Paulhus & Williams 2002"/><ref name="HorowitzPh.D.2010">{{cite book|author1=Leonard M. Horowitz|author2=Stephen Strack, Ph.D.|title=Handbook of Interpersonal Psychology: Theory, Research, Assessment and Therapeutic Interventions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VW-j6Lvxy_kC&pg=PA252|accessdate=15 February 2012|date=14 October 2010|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-88103-3|pages=252–55}}</ref><ref name="Lacey2009">{{cite book|author=David Lacey|title=Managing the Human Factor in Information Security: How to Win Over Staff and Influence Business Managers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EMyAJP1lEcUC&pg=PT248|date=17 March 2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-72199-5|page=248}}</ref>
Research on the dark triad is used in [[applied psychology]], especially within the fields of [[law enforcement]], [[clinical psychology]], and [[business management]]. People scoring high on these traits are more likely to commit crimes, cause social distress and create severe problems for an organization, especially if they are in leadership positions (for more information, see [[Psychopathy in the workplace|psychopathy]], [[Narcissism in the workplace|narcissism]], and [[Machiavellianism in the workplace]]).
All three dark triad traits are conceptually distinct although empirical evidence shows them to be overlapping. They are associated with a callous-manipulative interpersonal style.<ref>{{cite book |author=Jones, D. N., Paulhus, D. L. |chapter=Differentiating the dark triad within the interpersonal circumplex |editor1=Horowitz, L. M.,|editor2=Strack, S. N.|title=Handbook of interpersonal theory and research |publisher=Guilford |location=New York |year=2010 |pages=249–67 }}</ref>
* [[Narcissism]] is characterized by [[grandiosity]], [[pride]], [[egotism]], and a lack of [[empathy]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Kohut, H. |title=The Restoration of the Self |publisher=International Universities Press |location=New York |year=1977 }}</ref> * [[Machiavellianism]] is characterized by [[Psychological manipulation|manipulation]] and exploitation of others, a cynical disregard for [[morality]], and a focus on [[self-interest]] and [[deception]].<ref name=Jakobwitz>{{cite journal |author1=Jakobwitz, S. |author2=Egan, V. |title=The 'dark triad' and normal personality traits |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=40 |pages=331–39 |year=2006 |url=https://leicester.academia.edu/VincentEgan/Papers/45043/The_dark_triad_and_personality |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2005.07.006 |issue=2 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929002632/http://leicester.academia.edu/VincentEgan/Papers/45043/The_dark_triad_and_personality |archivedate=2012-09-29 |df= }}</ref> * [[Psychopathy]] is characterized by continuing [[anti-social behavior|antisocial behavior]], [[impulsivity]], [[selfishness]], callousness, and [[remorselessness]].<ref name="gap">{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/1529100611426706 |title=Psychopathic Personality: Bridging the Gap Between Scientific Evidence and Public Policy |year=2011 |last1=Skeem |first1=J. L. |last2=Polaschek |first2=D. L. L. |last3=Patrick |first3=C. J. |last4=Lilienfeld |first4=S. O. |journal=Psychological Science in the Public Interest |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=95–162 |url=http://www.psychologicalscience.org/index.php/publications/journals/pspi/psychopathy.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222023333/http://www.psychologicalscience.org/index.php/publications/journals/pspi/psychopathy.html |archivedate=2016-02-22 |df= }}</ref>
A [[factor analysis]] carried out at the [[Glasgow Caledonian University]] found that among the [[big five personality traits]], low [[agreeableness]] is the strongest correlate of the dark triad, while [[neuroticism]] and a lack of [[conscientiousness]] were associated with some of the dark triad members.<ref name=Jakobwitz/>
==History== {{See also|History of narcissism|History of psychopathy}} In 1998, McHoskey, Worzel, and Szyarto<ref>{{cite journal|author1=McHoskey J. W.|author2=Worzel W.|author3=Szyarto C.| year = 1998| title = Machiavellianism and psychopathy| url =| journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology| volume = 74| issue = 1| pages = 192–210| doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.74.1.192| pmid = 9457782 }}</ref> provoked a controversy by claiming that narcissism, Machiavellianism, and psychopathy are more or less interchangeable in normal samples. [[Delroy L. Paulhus]] and McHoskey debated these perspectives at a subsequent [[American Psychological Association]] (APA) conference, inspiring a body of research that continues to grow in the published literature. Paulhus and Williams found enough behavioral, personality, and cognitive differences between the traits to suggest that they were distinct constructs; however, they concluded that further research was needed to elucidate how and why they overlap.<ref name="Paulhus & Williams 2002"/>
==Origins== The long-debated "[[nature versus nurture]]" issue has been applied to the dark triad. Research has begun to investigate the origins of the dark triad traits. In a similar manner to research on the [[Big Five personality traits]], empirical studies have been conducted in an effort to understand the relative contributions of biology (nature) and environmental factors (nurture) in the development of dark triad traits.
One of the ways in which researchers attempt to dissect the relative influence of genetic and environmental factors on personality (and individual differences more generally) is a broad investigative technique loosely grouped under the heading of "twin studies". For example, in one approach to twin studies,<ref name="Petrides, Vernon, Schermer, Veselka 2011">{{cite journal |last1=Petrides |first1=K. V. |last2=Vernon |first2=Philip A. |last3=Schermer |first3=Julie Aitken |last4=Veselka |first4=Livia |title=Trait Emotional Intelligence and the Dark Triad Traits of Personality |journal=Twin Research and Human Genetics |date=February 2011 |volume=14 |issue=01 |pages=35–41 |doi=10.1375/twin.14.1.35}}</ref><ref name="Vernon, Martin, Schermer, Mackie 2008">{{cite journal |last1=Vernon |first1=Philip A. |last2=Martin |first2=Rod A. |last3=Schermer |first3=Julie Aitken |last4=Mackie |first4=Ashley |title=A behavioral genetic investigation of humor styles and their correlations with the Big-5 personality dimensions |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=April 2008 |volume=44 |issue=5 |pages=1116–1125 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2007.11.003}}</ref> <ref name = "Vernon, Villani, Vickers, Harris 2008">{{cite journal|last1=Vernon|first1=P.A.|last2=Villani|first2=V.C.|last3=Vickers|first3=L.C.|last4=Harris|first4=J.A.|title=A behavioral genetic investigation of the Dark Triad and the Big 5|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|date=2008|volume=44|issue=2|pages=445–452|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2007.09.007}}</ref> researchers compare the personality scores of monozygotic (MZ) or identical twins reared together to dizygotic (DZ) or fraternal twins reared together. Because both types of twins in this design are reared together, all twin pairs are regarded as having shared a 100% common environment. In contrast, the monozygotic twins share 100% of their genes whereas the dizygotic twins only share about 50% of their genes. Therefore, for any given personality trait, it is possible to parcel out genetic influences by first obtaining the MZ correlation (reflecting 100% common environment and 100% shared genes) and subtracting the DZ correlation (reflecting 100% common environment and 50% shared genes). This difference represents 50% of the genetic influence; doubled, this number is said to account for 100% of the genetic influence, and is one way to derive an index of heritability (sometimes called the heritability coefficient and represented as h<sup>2</sup>). Similarly, MZ - h<sup>2</sup> may be regarded as an estimate of the influence of the common environment. Finally, because individual differences and the environment are supposed to account for the totality of behavior, it is said that subtracting the sum of h<sup>2</sup> and the common environment influence from 1 is equal to the influence of unique or non-shared environments.
===Biological=== All three traits of the dark triad have been found to have substantial genetic components.<ref name="Petrides, Vernon, Schermer, Veselka 2011"/> It has also been found that the observed relationships among the dark triad, and among the dark triad and the Big Five, are strongly driven by individual differences in genes.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Furnham|first1=A.|last2=Richards|first2=S.C.|last3=Paulhus|first3=D.L.|title=The Dark Triad of personality: A 10 year review|journal=Social and Personality Psychology Compass|date=2013|volume=7|issue=3|pages=199–216|doi=10.1111/spc3.12018}}</ref> However, while psychopathy (h<sup>2</sup> = 0.64) and narcissism (h<sup>2</sup> = 0.59) both have a relatively large heritable component, Machiavellianism (h<sup>2</sup> = 0.31) has been found to be less heritable.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name= "Vernon, Villani, Vickers, Harris 2008"/>
===Environmental=== Compared to biological factors, the influence of environmental factors seem to be more subtle and account for less—yet still significant—variation in individual differences as related to the development of dark triad traits.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The influence of non-shared or unique environmental factors (definition and mathematical derivation included above at the end of the "Origins" subsection) accounts for a significant amount of the variance in all 3 dark triad traits (narcissism = 0.41, Machiavellianism = 0.30, psychopathy = 0.32), whereas only Machiavellianism (r = 0.39) has been found to be significantly related to a shared environmental factor.<ref name="Vernon, Martin, Schermer, Mackie 2008"/> Although it requires substantiation, some researchers have interpreted this latter finding (along with the comparatively lower heritability noted in the section above) to mean that Machiavellianism is the most likely dark triad trait to be influenced by experience.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal |last1=Jones |first1=Daniel N. |last2=Paulhus |first2=Delroy L. |title=The role of impulsivity in the Dark Triad of personality |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=October 2011 |volume=51 |issue=5 |pages=679–682 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.04.011}}</ref> At the very least, this notion about the modifiability of Machiavellianism does make some sense insofar as that the less variance there is attributable to genetic factors, the more variance there must be attributable to other factors, and "other" factors have traditionally been synopsized as environmental or experiential in nature.
===Evolutionary=== [[Evolutionary theory|Evolutionary]] [[Scientific theory|theory]] may also explain the development of dark triad traits. It has been argued that evolutionary behavior predicts not only the development of dark triad personalities, but also the flourishing of such personalities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mealey|first1=L.|title=The sociobiology of sociopathy: An integrated evolutionary model|journal=Behavioral and Brain Sciences|date=1995|volume=18|issue=03|pages=523–541|doi=10.1017/s0140525x00039595}}</ref> Indeed, it has been found that individuals demonstrating dark triad personality can be highly successful in society.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> However, this success is typically short-lived.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The main evolutionary argument behind the dark triad traits emphasizes mating strategies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jonason|first1=P.K.|last2=Webster|first2=G.D.|last3=Schmitt|first3=D.P.|title=The dark triad: Facilitating a short-term mating strategy in men|journal=European Journal of Personality|date=2009|volume=23|issue=1|pages=5–18|doi=10.1002/per.698}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brumbach|first1=B.H.|last2=Figueredo|first2=A.J.|last3=Ellis|first3=B.J.|title=Effects of harsh and unpredictable environments in adolescence on development of life history strategies|journal=Human Nature|date=2009|volume=20|issue=1|pages=25–51|doi=10.1007/s12110-009-9059-3|pmc=2903759}}</ref> This argument focuses on the notion of life history strategy.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal|last1=Rushton|first1=J.P.|title=Differential K theory: The sociobiology of individual and group differences|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|date=1985|volume=6|issue=4|pages=441–452|doi=10.1016/0191-8869(85)90137-0}}</ref> Life history strategy proposes that individuals differ in reproductive strategies; an emphasis on mating is termed a "fast life" strategy, while an emphasis on parenting is termed a "slow reproductive" strategy.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> There is some evidence <ref name="Jonason, Tost 2010">{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Tost |first2=Jeremy |title=I just cannot control myself: The Dark Triad and self-control |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=October 2010 |volume=49 |issue=6 |pages=611–615 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2010.05.031}}</ref><ref name="Jonason, Koenig, Tost 2010">{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Koenig |first2=Bryan L. |last3=Tost |first3=Jeremy |title=Living a fast life: The Dark Triad and Life History Theory |journal=Human Nature |date=19 November 2010 |volume=21 |issue=4 |pages=428–442 |doi=10.1007/s12110-010-9102-4}}</ref> that the dark triad traits are related to fast life history strategies; however, there have been some mixed results, and not all three dark triad traits have been related to this strategy. A more detailed approach<ref name="McDonald, Donnellan, Navarrete 2012">{{cite journal |last1=McDonald |first1=Melissa M. |last2=Donnellan |first2=M. Brent |last3=Navarrete |first3=Carlos David |title=A life history approach to understanding the Dark Triad |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=April 2012 |volume=52 |issue=5 |pages=601–605 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.12.003}}</ref> has attempted to account for some of these mixed results by analyzing the traits at a finer level of detail. These researchers found that while some components of the dark triad are related to a fast life strategy, other components are related to slow reproductive strategies.<ref name="McDonald, Donnellan, Navarrete 2012"/>
===Sub-clinical dimensions vs. disorders=== {{See also|Personality disorder}} In general, clinicians treat these traits as [[pathological]], something that needs to be treated, and inherently undesirable, e.g. socially condemned or personally counter-productive. However, others argue that adaptive qualities may accompany the maladaptive ones. The evolutionary perspective (above) considers the dark triad to represent different mating strategies. Their frequency in the gene pool requires at least some local adaptation.
The everyday versions of these traits appear in student and community samples, where even high levels can be observed among individuals who manage to get along in daily life. Even in these samples, research indicates correlations with [[aggression]],<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Jones D.N.|author2=Paulhus D. L.| year = 2010| title = Different provocations trigger aggression in narcissists and psychopaths|journal=Social Psychological and Personality Science|volume = 1|pages =12–18|doi=10.1177/1948550609347591}}</ref> [[racism]],<ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Hodson| first1 = G. M.| last2 = Hogg| first2 = S. M.| last3 = MacInnis| first3 = C. C.| year = 2009| title = The role of "dark personalities" (narcissism, Machiavellianism, psychopathy), Big Five personality factors, and ideology in explaining prejudice| url =| journal = Journal of Research in Personality| volume = 43| issue =| pages = 686–690| doi=10.1016/j.jrp.2009.02.005}}</ref> and [[bullying]]<ref name="Contributions to juvenile delinquency">{{cite journal|author1=Chabrol H.|author2=Van Leeuwen N.|author3=Rodgers R.|author4=Séjourné S.| year = 2009| title = Contributions of psychopathic, narcissistic, Machiavellian, and sadistic personality traits to juvenile delinquency|journal = Personality and Individual Differences|volume =47|issue=7|pages=734–39|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2009.06.020 }}</ref> among other forms of social aversiveness.
Narcissism was discussed in the writings of [[Sigmund Freud]], and psychopathy as a clinical diagnosis was addressed in the early writings of [[Hervey Cleckley]] in 1941 with the publication of ''[[The Mask of Sanity]]''.<ref>Cleckly, H. C. (1941). The Mask of Sanity: An Attempt to Reinterpret the So-Called Psychopathic Personality. St. Louis, MO: Mosby.</ref> Given the dimensional model of narcissism and psychopathy, complemented by self-report assessments that are appropriate for the general population, these traits can now be studied at the subclinical level.<ref>LeBreton, J. M., Binning, J. F., & Adorno, A. J. (2005). Sub-clinical psychopaths. In D. L. Segal & J. C. Thomas (Eds.), Comprehensive handbook of personality and psychopathology: Vol. 1. Personality and everyday functioning (pp. 388–411). New York: John Wiley.</ref> In the general population, the prevalence rates for sub-clinical and clinical psychopathy are estimated at around 1% and 0.2%, respectively.<ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Babiak| first1 = P.| last2 = Neumann| first2 = C. S.| last3 = Hare| first3 = R. D.| year = 2010| title = Corporate psychopathy: Talking the walk| url =| journal = Behavioral Sciences & The Law| volume = 28| issue =| pages = 174–193| doi = 10.1002/bsl.925| pmid=20422644}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Coid| first1 = J.| last2 = Yang| first2 = M.| last3 = Ullrich| first3 = S.| last4 = Roberts| first4 = A.| last5 = Hare| first5 = R. D.| year = 2009| title = Prevalence and correlates of psychopathic traits in the household population of Great Britain| url =| journal = International Journal of Law and Psychiatry| volume = 32| issue =| pages = 65–73| doi = 10.1016/j.ijlp.2009.01.002| pmid=19243821}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Neumann| first1 = C. S.| last2 = Hare| first2 = R. D.| year = 2008| title = Psychopathic traits in a large community sample: Links to violence, alcohol use, and intelligence| doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.76.5.893| journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology| volume = 76| issue =| pages = 893–899| pmid=18837606}}</ref> Unfortunately, there do not seem to be any reliable estimates of either clinical or sub-clinical narcissism in the general population.<ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Foster| first1 = J. D.| last2 = Campbell| first2 = W. K.| year = 2007| title = Are there such things as "narcissists" in social psychology? A taxometric analysis of the Narcissistic Personality Inventory| url =| journal = Personality and Individual Differences| volume = 43| issue = 6| pages = 1321–1332| doi=10.1016/j.paid.2007.04.003}}</ref>
With respect to empirical research, psychopathy was not formally studied until the 1970s with the pioneering efforts of [[Robert D. Hare|Robert Hare]], his [[Psychopathy Checklist]] (PCL), and its revision (PCL-R).<ref>Hare, R.D., (1991). The Hare Psychopathy Checklist-Revised. Toronto: Multi-Health Systems.</ref> Hare notes in his book, ''Without Conscience'' <ref>Hare, R. D. (1999). ''Without conscience: The disturbing world of the psychopaths among us''. New York: Guilford Press.</ref> that asking psychopaths to self-report on psychologically important matters does not necessarily provide accurate or unbiased data. However, recent efforts have been made to study psychopathy in the dimensional realm using self-reported instruments, as with the Levenson Primary and Secondary Psychopathy Scales,<ref name="Levenson M. R., Kiehl K. A., Fitzpatrick C. M. 1995 151–58">{{cite journal|author1=Levenson M. R.|author2=Kiehl K. A.|author3=Fitzpatrick C. M.| year = 1995| title = Assessing psychopathic attributes in a noninstitutionalized population| url =| journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology| volume = 68| issue = 1| pages = 151–58| doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.68.1.151| pmid = 7861311 }}</ref> The Psychopathic Personality Inventory,<ref name="Lilienfeld S. O., Andrews B. P. 1996 488–524">{{cite journal|author1=Lilienfeld S. O.|author2=Andrews B. P.| year = 1996| title = Development and preliminary validation of a self-report measure of psychopathic personality traits in noncrimnal population| journal = Journal of Personality Assessment| volume = 66| issue = 3| pages = 488–524| doi = 10.1207/s15327752jpa6603_3| pmid = 8667144 }}</ref> and the Self-Report Psychopathy Scale.<ref>Paulhus, D. L., Neumann, C. S., & Hare, R. D. (2015). Manual for the Self-Report Psychopathy scales (4th ed.). Toronto, Canada: Multi-Health Systems.</ref>
Similarly, assessment of narcissism required clinical interviews, until the popular "[[Narcissistic Personality Inventory]]" was created by Raskin and Hall in 1979.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Raskin R.|author2=Hall C. S.| year = 1979| title = A Narcissistic Personality Inventory| journal = Psychological Reports|volume = 45| issue = 2| page = 590| doi = 10.2466/pr0.1979.45.2.590 }}</ref> Since the NPI, several other measures have emerged which attempt to provide self-report alternatives for personality disorder assessment.<ref>Hyler, S.E. (1994). Personality Diagnostic Questionnaire-4 (Unpublished test). New York: NYSPI.</ref> In addition, new instruments have been developed to study "pathological" narcissism <ref>{{cite journal|author1=Pincus A. L.|author2=Ansell E. B.|author3=Pimentel C. A.|author4=Cain N. M.|author5=Wright A. G. C.|author6=Levy K. N.| year = 2009|title = Initial construction and validation of the Pathological Narcissism Inventory| url =| journal = Psychological Assessment| volume = 21|issue = 3|pages = 365–79|doi=10.1037/a0016530|pmid=19719348}}</ref> as opposed to "grandiose" narcissism, which is what many argue the NPI measures.<ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Miller| first1 = J. D.| last2 = Campbell| first2 = W. K.| year = 2008| title = Comparing clinical and Social-Personality Conceptutalizations of narcissism| url =| journal = Journal of Personality| volume = 76| issue =| pages = 449–476| doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.2008.00492.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| author = Wink P| year = 1991| title = Two faces of narcissism| journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology| volume = 61| issue = 4| pages = 590–97| doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.61.4.590| pmid = 1960651 }}</ref>
Machiavellianism has never been referenced in any version of the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]]'' (DSM) for psychological disorders. It has been treated as strictly a personality construct. The original published version of the Mach-IV <ref>Christie, R., & Geis, F. L. (1970). Studies in Machiavellianism. New York: Academic Press.</ref> is still the most widely used in empirical research.<ref>Jones, D. N., & Paulhus, D. L. (2009). Machiavellianism. In M. R. Leary & R. H. Hoyle (Eds.), Handbook of Individual Differences in Social Behavior (pp. 93–108). New York: Guilford.</ref>
==Components== [[File:Jimmy Savile 2006.jpg|thumb|125px|English presenter [[Jimmy Savile]] exhibited the dark triad.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jun/26/inside-the-mind-of-jimmy-savile|title=Inside the mind of Jimmy Savile|last=James|first=Oliver|authorlink=Oliver James (psychologist)|date=26 June 2014|website=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=17 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161214172206/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jun/26/inside-the-mind-of-jimmy-savile|archivedate=14 December 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/opinion/14432749.Why_you_shouldn_t_ignore_your_creepiness_alert/|title=Why you shouldn't ignore your creepiness alert|last=Burns|first=Val|date=17 April 2016|website=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]|access-date=20 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220231355/http://www.heraldscotland.com/opinion/14432749.Why_you_shouldn_t_ignore_your_creepiness_alert/|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=}}</ref>]] As noted previously, there is a good deal of conceptual and empirical overlap between the dark triad traits. For example, researchers have noted that all three traits share characteristics such as a lack of empathy,<ref name="ReferenceB"/> interpersonal hostility,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lynam|first1=D.R.|last2=Gaughan|first2=E.T.|title=Assessing the basic traits associated with psychopathy: Development and validation of the Elemental Psychopathy Assessment|journal=Psychological Assessment|date=2011|volume=23|issue=1|doi=10.1037/a0021146}}</ref> and interpersonal offensiveness.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Egan|first1=V.|last2=McCorkindale|first2=C.|title=Narcissism, vanity, personality and mating effort|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|date=2007|volume=43|issue=8|pages=2105–2115|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2007.06.034}}</ref> Likely due in part to this overlap, a number of measures have recently been developed that attempt to measure all three dark triad traits simultaneously, such as the Dirty Dozen <ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Webster |first2=Gregory D. |title=The dirty dozen: A concise measure of the dark triad. |journal=Psychological Assessment |date=2010 |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=420–432 |doi=10.1037/a0019265}}</ref> and the short dark triad (SD3).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jones|first1=D.N.|last2=Paulhus|first2=D.L.|title=Introducing the Short Dark Triad (SD3) A Brief Measure of Dark Personality Traits|journal=Assessment|date=2014|volume=21|issue=1|pages=28–41|doi=10.1177/1073191113514105}}</ref>
At their root, however, most of these measures are questionnaire-style and require either self-response or observer-response (e.g., ratings from supervisors or coworkers). Both methods can prove problematic when attempting to measure any socially aversive trait as self-responders may be motivated to deceive.<ref name="social exchange perspective 2012">{{cite journal|last1=O'Boyle|first1=E.H.|last2=Forsyth|first2=D.R.|last3=Banks|first3=G.C.|last4=McDaniel|first4=M.A.|title=A meta-analysis of the dark triad and work behavior: A social exchange perspective|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|date=2012|volume=97|issue=3|pages=557–79|doi=10.1037/a0025679|pmid=22023075|url=https://zenodo.org/record/850152|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827205904/https://zenodo.org/record/850152|archivedate=2017-08-27|df=}}</ref> A more specific confound might also exist for dark triad traits and Machiavellianism in particular: individuals who are skilled at deceiving and manipulating others should be perceived as low in deceptiveness and manipulation by others, and are therefore likely to receive inaccurate ratings.<ref name="social exchange perspective 2012"/>
Despite these criticisms and the acknowledged commonalities among the dark triad traits, there is evidence that the constructs are related yet distinct.
===Machiavellianism=== Named after the philosophy espoused by Niccolò Machiavelli in ''[[The Prince]]'', people who score high on this trait are cynical (in an amoral self-interest sense, not in a doubtful or skeptical sense), unprincipled, believe in interpersonal manipulation as the key for life success, and behave accordingly.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Scores on measures of [[Machiavellianism]] correlate negatively with [[agreeableness]] (r= -.47) and [[conscientiousness]] (r=-.34).<ref name="Paulhus & Williams 2002"/> Machiavellianism is also significantly correlated with [[psychopathy]].<ref name="Vernon, Villani, Vickers, Harris 2008"/>
===Narcissism=== Individuals who score high on [[narcissism]] display grandiosity, entitlement, dominance, and superiority.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Corry|first1=N.|last2=Merritt|first2=R.D.|last3=Mrug|first3=S.|last4=Pamp|first4=B.|title=The factor structure of the Narcissistic Personality Inventory|journal=Journal of Personality Assessment|date=2008|volume=90|issue=6|pages=593–600|doi=10.1080/00223890802388590}}</ref> Narcissism has been found to correlate positively with [[extraversion]] (r = .42) and [[openness]] (r = .38) and negatively with [[agreeableness]] (r = -.36).<ref name="Paulhus & Williams 2002"/> Narcissism has also been found to have a significant correlation with [[psychopathy]].<ref name="Vernon, Villani, Vickers, Harris 2008"/>
===Psychopathy=== Considered the most malevolent of the dark triad,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rauthmann|first1=J.F.|title=The Dark Triad and interpersonal perception: Similarities and differences in the social consequences of narcissism, Machiavellianism, and psychopathy|journal=Social Psychological and Personality Science|date=2012|volume=3|issue=4|pages=487–496|doi=10.1177/1948550611427608}}</ref> individuals who score high on [[psychopathy]] show low levels of empathy combined with high levels of impulsivity and thrill-seeking.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hare|first1=R.D.|title=Comparison of procedures for the assessment of psychopathy|journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology|date=1985|volume=53|issue=1|pages=7–16|doi=10.1037/0022-006x.53.1.7}}</ref> The similarity between psychopathy and [[antisocial personality disorder]] have been noted by some researchers.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Psychopathy has been found to correlate with all of the Big Five personality factors: [[extraversion]] (r = .34), [[agreeableness]] (r = -.25), [[conscientiousness]] (r = -.24), [[neuroticism]] (r = -.34) and [[openness]] (r = .24).<ref name="Vernon, Villani, Vickers, Harris 2008"/>
==Group differences== The most pronounced group difference is in gender: numerous studies have shown that men tend to score higher than women on narcissism,<ref name="Egos inflating over time 2008">{{cite journal |last1=Twenge |first1=Jean M. |last2=Konrath |first2=Sara |last3=Foster |first3=Joshua D. |last4=Keith Campbell |first4=W. |last5=Bushman |first5=Brad J. |title=Egos Inflating Over Time: A Cross-Temporal Meta-Analysis of the Narcissistic Personality Inventory |journal=Journal of Personality |date=August 2008 |volume=76 |issue=4 |pages=875–902 |doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.2008.00507.x}}</ref> Machiavellianism,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chonko|first1=L.B.|title=). Machiavellianism: Sex differences in the profession of purchasing management|journal=Psychological Reports|date=1982|volume=51|issue=2|pages=645–646|doi=10.2466/pr0.1982.51.2.645}}</ref><ref name="new Machiavellianism scale">{{cite journal|last1=Dahling|first1=J.J.|last2=Whitaker|first2=B.G.|last3=Levy|first3=P.E.|title=The development and validation of a new Machiavellianism scale|date=2008|doi=10.1177/0149206308318618|volume=35|journal=Journal of Management|pages=219–257}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wertheim|first1=E.G.|last2=Widom|first2=C.S.|last3=Wortzel|first3=L.H.|title=Multivariate analysis of male and female professional career choice correlates|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|date=1978|volume=63|issue=2|pages=234–242|doi=10.1037/0021-9010.63.2.234}}</ref> and psychopathy,<ref name="Levenson M. R., Kiehl K. A., Fitzpatrick C. M. 1995 151–58"/><ref name="Lilienfeld S. O., Andrews B. P. 1996 488–524"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cale|first1=E.M.|last2=Lilienfeld|first2=S.O.|title=Sex differences in psychopathy and antisocial personality disorder: A review and integration|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|date=2002|volume=22|issue=8|pages=1179–1207|doi=10.1016/s0272-7358(01)00125-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zagon|first1=I.K.|last2=Jackson|first2=H.J.|title=Construct validity of a psychopathy measure|journal=Journal of Personality and Individual Differences|date=1994|pages=125–135}}</ref> although the magnitude of the difference varies across traits and the measurement instruments used. One interesting finding related to narcissism—albeit one based on non-representative samples—is that while men continue to score higher than women, it seems that the gender gap has shrunk considerably when comparing cohort data from 1992 and 2006. More specifically, the aforementioned findings indicate that there has been a general increase in levels of narcissism over time among college students of both sexes, but comparatively, the average level of narcissism in women has increased more than the average level of narcissism in men.<ref name="Egos inflating over time 2008"/>
There is far less information available on race differences in dark triad traits, and the data that is available is not representative of the population at-large. For instance, a 2008 research study using undergraduate participants found that Caucasians reported higher levels of narcissism relative to Asians.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Trzesniewski|first1=K.H.|last2=Donnellan|first2=M.B.|title=Do today's young people really think they are so extraordinary? An examination of secular trends in narcissism and self-enhancement|journal=Psychological Science|date=2008|volume=19|issue=2|pages=181–188|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9280.2008.02065.x|pmid=18271867}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Twenge|first1=J.M.|last2=Foster|first2=J.D.|title=Mapping the scale of the narcissism epidemic: Increases in narcissism 2002–2007 within ethnic groups|journal=Journal of Research in Personality|date=2008|volume=42|issue=6|pages=1619–1622|doi=10.1016/j.jrp.2008.06.014}}</ref> Similarly, another 2008 study using undergraduate participants found that Caucasians tended to score slightly higher than non-Caucasians on Machiavellianism.<ref name="new Machiavellianism scale"/> When attempting to discern whether there are ethnic differences in psychopathy, researchers have addressed the issue using different measurement instruments (e.g., the Self-Report Psychopathy Scale and The Psychopathic Personality Inventory), but no race differences have been found regardless of the measure used.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Epstein|first1=M.K.|last2=Poythress|first2=N.G.|last3=Brandon|first3=K.O.|title=The Self-Report Psychopathy Scale and Passive Avoidance Learning A Validation Study of Race and Gender Effects|journal=Assessment|date=2006|volume=13|issue=2|pages=197–207|doi=10.1177/1073191105284992}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lander|first1=G.C.|last2=Lutz-ZOis|first2=C.J.|last3=Rye|first3=M.S.|last4=Goodnight|first4=J.A.|title=The differential association between alexithymia and primary versus secondary psychopathy|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|date=2012|volume=52|issue=1|pages=45–50|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.08.027}}</ref> Additionally, when comparing Caucasians and African Americans from correctional, substance abuse, and psychiatric samples—groups with typically high prevalence rates of psychopathy—researchers again failed to find any meaningful group differences in psychopathy.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Skeem|first1=J.L.|last2=Edens|first2=J.F.|last3=Camp|first3=J.|last4=Colwell|first4=L.H.|title=Are there ethnic differences in levels of psychopathy? A meta-analysis|journal=Law and human behavior|date=2004|volume=28|issue=5|pages=505–527|doi=10.1023/b:lahu.0000046431.93095.d8}}</ref> However, in a research conducted by [[Richard Lynn]], a substantial racial difference in psychopathy was found. Lynn proposes "that there are racial and ethnic differences in psychopathic personality conceptualised as a continuously distributed trait, such that high values of the trait are present in blacks and Native Americans, intermediate values in Hispanics, lower values in whites and the lowest values in East Asians."<ref>{{cite web|url=http:// https://www.researchgate.net/publication/222191018_Racial_and_ethnic_differences_in_psychopathic_personality|title=Racial and ethnic differences in psychopathic personality |website=Research Gate}}</ref>
The focal variable when analyzing generational or cohort differences in dark triad traits has tended to be narcissism, arising from the hypothesis that so-called “[[Generation Me]]” or “Generation Entitlement” would exhibit higher levels of narcissism than previous generations. Indeed, based on analyses of responses to the [[Narcissistic Personality Inventory]] collected from over 16,000 U.S. undergraduate students between 1979 and 2006, it was concluded that average levels of narcissism had increased over time.<ref name="Egos inflating over time 2008"/> Similar results were obtained in a follow-up study that analyzed the changes within each college campus.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Twenge|first1=J.M.|last2=Campbell|first2=W.K.|title=Birth Cohort Differences in the Monitoring the Future Dataset and Elsewhere Further Evidence for Generation Me—Commentary on Trzesniewski & Donnellan|journal=Perspectives on Psychological Science|date=2010|volume=5|issue=1|pages=81–88|doi=10.1177/1745691609357015}}</ref> Trzesniewski & Donnellan (2010)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Trzesniewski|first1=K.H.|last2=Donnellan|first2=M.B.|title=Rethinking "Generation Me" a study of cohort effects from 1976–2006|journal=Perspectives on Psychological Science|date=2010|volume=5|issue=1|pages=58–75|doi=10.1177/1745691609356789}}</ref> present conflicting evidence and argue that there have not been large changes in disposition or behavioral strategies across generations, although they do note that the current generation is less trusting and more cynical, which are both changes that might be indicative of an increase in Machiavellianism.
==Perspectives==
===In the workplace=== [[Oliver James (psychologist)|Oliver James]] identifies each of the three dark triadic personality traits as typically being prevalent in the [[workplace]] (see also [[Machiavellianism in the workplace]], [[narcissism in the workplace]] and [[psychopathy in the workplace]]).<ref>James O Office Politics: How to Thrive in a World of Lying, Backstabbing and Dirty Tricks (2013)</ref> Furnham <ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = The dark triad of personality: A ten year review|last = Furnham|first = Adrian|date = 2010|journal = Social and personality psychology compass|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> (2010) has identified that the dark triad is related to the acquisition of leadership positions and interpersonal influence. In a meta-analysis of dark triad and workplace outcomes, Jonason and colleagues (2012) found that each of the dark triad traits were related to manipulation in the workplace, but each via unique mechanisms. Specifically, Machiavellianism was related with the use of excessive charm in manipulation, narcissism was related with the use of physical appearance, and psychopathy was related with physical threats.<ref name="Jonason, Slomski, Partyka 2012">{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Slomski |first2=Sarah |last3=Partyka |first3=Jamie |title=The Dark Triad at work: How toxic employees get their way |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=February 2012 |volume=52 |issue=3 |pages=449–453 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.11.008}}</ref> Jonason and colleagues also found that the dark triad traits fully mediated the relationship between gender and workplace manipulation. The dark triad traits have also been found to be fairly well-represented in upper-level management and CEOs.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Accounting as a facilitator of extreme narcissism|last = Amernic|first = J.|date = 2010|journal = Journal of Business Ethics|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
===Internet trolls=== {{Main article|Troll (Internet)}} Recent studies have found that people who are identified as trolls tend to have dark personality traits and show signs of [[Antisocial personality disorder|sadism]], [[antisocial behavior]], psychopathy, and Machiavellianism.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Buckels | first1 = E.E. | last2 = Trapnell | first2 = P.D. | last3 = Paulhus | first3 = D.L. | year = 2013 | title = Trolls Just Want to Have Fun | url = | journal = Personality and Individual Differences| doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2014.01.016 | volume=67 | pages=97–102}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/your-online-secrets/201409/internet-trolls-are-narcissists-psychopaths-and-sadists | title = Internet Trolls Are Narcissists, Psychopaths, and Sadists}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/science/2014/02/science-confirms-online-trolls-are-horrible-people-also-sadists/ | title = Science confirms: Online trolls are horrible people (also, sadists!) | date = 20 February 2014 | accessdate = 2 November 2016 | publisher = ''Ars Technica'' | author = Nate Anderson | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161104004119/http://arstechnica.com/science/2014/02/science-confirms-online-trolls-are-horrible-people-also-sadists/ | archivedate = 4 November 2016 | df = }}</ref> The 2013 case study suggested that there are a number of similarities between anti-social and [[Flaming (Internet)|flame]] trolling activities and the 2014 survey indicated that trolling is an Internet manifestation of [[Sadistic personality disorder|everyday sadism]]. Both studies suggest that this trolling may be linked to [[bullying]] in both adolescents and adults.
===As a mating strategy=== Studies have suggested that on average, those who exhibit the dark triad of personality traits have an [[r/K selection theory|accelerated mating strategy]], reporting more sex partners, more favorable attitudes towards casual sex,<ref name="short-term mating">{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Li |first2=Norman P. |last3=Webster |first3=Gregory D. |last4=Schmitt |first4=David P. |title=The dark triad: Facilitating a short-term mating strategy in men |journal=European Journal of Personality |date=February 2009 |volume=23 |issue=1 |pages=5–18 |doi=10.1002/per.698}}</ref> lowered standards in their short-term mates,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Valentine |first2=Katherine A. |last3=Li |first3=Norman P. |last4=Harbeson |first4=Carmelita L. |title=Mate-selection and the Dark Triad: Facilitating a short-term mating strategy and creating a volatile environment |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=October 2011 |volume=51 |issue=6 |pages=759–763 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.06.025}}</ref> a tendency to steal or poach mates from others,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Li |first2=Norman P. |last3=Buss |first3=David M. |title=The costs and benefits of the Dark Triad: Implications for mate poaching and mate retention tactics |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=March 2010 |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=373–378 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2009.11.003}}</ref> more risk-taking in the form of substance abuse,<ref name="Jonason, Koenig, Tost 2010"/> a tendency to prefer immediate but smaller amounts of money over delayed but larger amounts of money,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jonason | first1 = P. K. | last2 = Li | first2 = N. P. | last3 = Teicher | first3 = E. A. | year = 2010 | title = Who is James Bond?:The Dark Triad as an agentic social style | url = | journal = Individual Differences Research | volume = 8 | issue = | pages = 111–120 }}</ref> limited [[self-control]] and greater incidence of [[ADHD]] symptoms<ref name="Jonason, Tost 2010"/> and a pragmatic and game-playing romance style.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Kavanagh |first2=Phillip |title=The dark side of love: Love styles and the Dark Triad |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=October 2010 |volume=49 |issue=6 |pages=606–610 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2010.05.030}}</ref> These traits have been identified as part of a [[R/K selection theory|fast life strategy]] that appears to be enacted by an exploitative, [[opportunistic]], and protean approach to life in general<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jonason |first1=Peter K. |last2=Webster |first2=Gregory D. |title=A protean approach to social influence: Dark Triad personalities and social influence tactics |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |date=March 2012 |volume=52 |issue=4 |pages=521–526 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.11.023}}</ref> and at work.<ref name="Jonason, Slomski, Partyka 2012"/>
The evidence is mixed regarding the exact link between the dark triad and reproductive success. For example, there is a lack of empirical evidence for reproductive success in the case of psychopathy.<ref name="gap"/> Additionally, these traits are not universally short-term-oriented<ref name="Jonason, Tost 2010"/> nor are they all impulsive.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Furthermore, much of the research reported pertaining to the dark triad cited in the above paragraph is based on statistical procedures that assume the dark triad are a single construct, in spite of genetic <ref name = "Vernon, Villani, Vickers, Harris 2008"/> and meta-analytic evidence to the contrary.<ref name="social exchange perspective 2012"/>
See also: [[r/K selection theory]] (connection remains controversial).<ref>[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/147470491201000303 What Have You Done for Me Lately? Friendship-Selection in the Shadow of the Dark Triad Traits Peter K. Jonason, David P. Schmitt]</ref>
===Appearance=== Several academic studies have found evidence that people with dark triad personalities are judged as slightly better-looking than average on first sight.<ref>Carter, Gregory Louis, Anne C. Campbell, Steven Muncer, "[http://scottbarrykaufman.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/The-Dark-Triad-Personality.pdf The Dark Triad personality: Attractiveness to women] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150226020227/http://scottbarrykaufman.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/The-Dark-Triad-Personality.pdf |date=2015-02-26 }}", ''[[Elsevier]]/[[ScienceDirect]]'', 12 June 2013</ref> Two studies have determined that this is because people with dark triad traits put more effort into their appearance, and the difference in attractiveness disappears when "dressed down" with bland clothing and without make up.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Grewel | first1 = Daisy | year = 2012 | title = Psychology Uncovers Sex Appeal of Dark Personalities | url = http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/psychology-uncovers-sex-appeal-dark-personalities/ | journal = [[Scientific American]] | volume = | issue = | page = | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150825175428/http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/psychology-uncovers-sex-appeal-dark-personalities/ | archivedate = 2015-08-25 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Holtzman | first1 = Nicholas | year = 2012 | title = People With Dark Personalities Tend to Create a Physically Attractive Veneer | url = http://spp.sagepub.com/content/early/2012/10/02/1948550612461284.abstract?rss=1 | journal = [[Social Psychological and Personality Science]] | volume = 4 | issue = | pages = 461–467 | doi = 10.1177/1948550612461284 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141229202404/http://spp.sagepub.com/content/early/2012/10/02/1948550612461284.abstract?rss=1 | archivedate = 2014-12-29 | df = }}</ref> Two more studies found that only narcissistic subjects were judged to be better-looking, but the other dark triad traits of machiavellianism and psychopathy had no correlation with looks.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = | first1 = | year = 2013 | title = Are Narcissists Sexy? Zeroing in on the Effect of Narcissism on Short-Term Mate Appeal | url = http://psp.sagepub.com/content/39/7/870.abstract | journal = [[Journal of Personality and Social Psychology]] | volume = 39 | issue = 7 | pages = 870–882 | doi = 10.1177/0146167213483580 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150404033000/http://psp.sagepub.com/content/39/7/870.abstract | archivedate = 2015-04-04 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Back | first1 = Schmuckle | last2 = Egloff | first2 = | date = Jan 2010 | title = Why are narcissists so charming at first sight? Decoding the narcissism-popularity link at zero acquaintance. | journal = [[Journal of Personality and Social Psychology]] | volume = 98 | issue = 1| pages = 132–45 | doi = 10.1037/a0016338 | pmid=20053038}}</ref>
==Related concepts==
=== Big Five === The [[Big Five personality traits|five factor model of personality]] has significant relationships with the dark triad combined and with each of the dark triad’s traits. The dark triad overall is negatively related to both [[agreeableness]] and [[conscientiousness]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> More specifically, Machiavellianism captures a suspicious versus trusting view of human nature which is also captured by the Trust sub-scale on the agreeableness trait.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Machiavellian beliefs and personality: Construct invalidity of the Machiavellianism dimension|last = Hunter|first = J. E.|date = 1982|journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.43.6.1293 |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 43|pages = 1293–1305|last2 = Gerbing|first2 = D. W.|first3 = F. J.|last3 = Boster}}</ref> [[Extroversion]] captures similar aspects of assertiveness, dominance, and self-importance as narcissism.<ref name=":1" /> Narcissism also is positively related to the achievement striving and competence aspects of Conscientiousness. Psychopathy has the strongest correlations with low dutifulness and deliberation aspects of Conscientiousness.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
=== Honesty-humility === The [[Honesty-humility factor of the HEXACO model of personality|honesty-humility]] factor from the [[HEXACO model of personality structure|HEXACO]] model of personality is used to measure sincerity, fairness, greed avoidance, and modesty. Honesty-Humility has been found to be strongly, negatively correlated to the dark triad traits.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Aghababaei | first1 = N. | last2 = Mohammadtabar | first2 = S. | last3 = Saffarinia | first3 = M. | year = 2014 | title = Dirty Dozen vs. the H factor: Comparison of the Dark Triad and Honesty–Humility in prosociality, religiosity, and happiness | url = | journal = Personality and Individual Differences | volume = 67 | issue = | pages = 6–10 | doi=10.1016/j.paid.2014.03.026}}</ref> Likewise, all three dark triad traits are strongly negatively correlated with Honesty-Humility.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The conceptual overlap of the three traits which represents a tendency to manipulate and exploit others for personal gain defines the negative pole of the honesty-humility factor.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lee | first1 = K. | last2 = Ashton | first2 = M. C. | last3 = Wiltshire | first3 = J. | last4 = Bourdage | first4 = J. S. | last5 = Visser | first5 = B. A. | last6 = Gallucci | first6 = A. | year = 2013 | title = Sex, power, and money: Prediction from the Dark Triad and Honesty–Humility | url = | journal = European Journal of Personality | volume = 27 | issue = 2| pages = 169–184 | doi=10.1002/per.1860}}</ref> Typically, any positive effects from the DT and low H-H occur at the individual level, that is, any benefits are conferred onto the beholder of the traits (e.g., successful mating, obtainment of leadership positions) and not onto others or society at large. A study found that individuals who score low in Honesty-Humility have higher levels of self-reported creativity.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Cantankerous creativity: Honesty–Humility, Agreeableness, and the HEXACO structure of creative achievement|last = Silvia|first = P|date = 2011|journal = Personality and Individual Differences|doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2011.06.011|pmid = |access-date = |last2 = Kaufman|first2 = J}}</ref>
===Dark tetrad=== Several researchers have suggested expanding the dark triad to contain a fourth dark trait. Everyday sadism, defined as the enjoyment of cruelty, is the most common addition.<ref name="apa-sadism">{{Cite news|url=https://www.psychologicalscience.org/news/releases/everyday-sadists-take-pleasure-in-others-pain.html|title=Everyday Sadists Take Pleasure In Others’ Pain|work=Association for Psychological Science|access-date=2018-05-26|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180527025804/https://www.psychologicalscience.org/news/releases/everyday-sadists-take-pleasure-in-others-pain.html|archivedate=2018-05-27|df=}}</ref> While sadism is highly correlated with the dark triad, researchers have shown that sadism predicts [[anti-social behavior]] beyond the dark triad.<ref name="Contributions to juvenile delinquency"/><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Buckels | first1 = E.E. | last2 = Jones | first2 = D. N. | last3 = Paulhus | first3 = D. L. | year = 2013 | title = Behavioral Confirmation of Everyday Sadism| url = | journal = Psychological Science | volume = 24 | issue = | pages = 2201–2209 | doi=10.1177/0956797613490749 | pmid=24022650}}</ref> [[Borderline personality disorder]] and status-driven risk-taking have also been proposed as additions.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===Vulnerable dark triad=== The vulnerable dark triad (VDT) comprises three related and similar constructs: vulnerable narcissism, factor 2 psychopathy, and [[borderline personality disorder]]. A study found that these three constructs are significantly related to one another and manifest similar [[nomological]] networks. Although the VDT members are related to negative emotionality and antagonistic interpersonal styles, they are also related to [[introversion]] and [[disinhibition]]. The study does note however that its findings are based largely on the self-reports of parents of White undergrad students rather than information gleaned from clinical evaluation.<ref name="vdt">{{cite journal | url=http://wkeithcampbell.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/VulnerableDarkTriad.pdf | title=Searching for a Vulnerable Dark Triad: Comparing Factor 2 Psychopathy, Vulnerable Narcissism, and Borderline Personality Disorder | author1=Miller, JD. | author2=Dir, A. | author3=Gentile, B. | author4=Wilson, L. | author5=Pryor, LR. | author6=Campbell, K. | journal=Journal of Personality | date=October 2010 | volume=78 | issue=5 | pages=1529–1564 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.2010.00660.x | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913131007/http://wkeithcampbell.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/VulnerableDarkTriad.pdf | archivedate=2014-09-13 | df= }}</ref>
=== Malignant narcissism === Within the clinical/pathological realm, narcissism can manifest itself in a particularly severe form known as [[malignant narcissism]]. Malignant narcissism presents not only with signs and symptoms of grandiose narcissism, but also includes features of paranoia, sadism, aggression, and psychopathy (particularly antisocial behaviors).<ref>[https://www.karger.com/Article/Abstract/492228 Lenzenweger] M.F., Clarkin J.F., Caligor E., Cain N.M., & Kernberg O.F. (2018). "Malignant Narcissism in Relation to Clinical Change in Borderline Personality Disorder: An Exploratory Study". Psychopathology. doi:10.1159/000492228.</ref>
